That quote from Isaac Newton is a response to a letter form Richard Bentley. Mr Bentley was trying to get clarification on Newton's work before he delivered a sermon or lecture on the. He was talking about how gravity is a phenomenon that just seems to be a something that all matter has, but there isn't a good explanation for why. He thought it was just a fact of nature that matter has gravity as an innate property. Newton may have understood the mathematics of gravity and could predict how objects would behave, but he wanted to be adamant that he did not understand WHY matter has gravity, and he would very much prefer it that Bentley not use Newton as a source that claims that matter has gravity as an innate property.

Correct me if I am wrong.  As you look at different distances from the Earth, you are also looking at different time in the age of the universe.  So if you look at the CMB, you are looking at something that has lasted almost the entire age of the universe.  But if you look at objects closer to the Earth, you are looking at more recent phenomenon.  It is entirely possible that the Hubble constant is different at different times of the universe.  The universe is expanding at different rate at different times.  We know that from cosmology.  So, if the the Hubble constant from CMB is different from that from the supernova, I am not surprised, unless the observed values differ significantly from the theoretical prediction, given the best model of the universe that we have.

In just over 1600 years, Mercury will explode into our binary star, followed by Venus, Earth, Mars and so on. Each binary explosion, which sends thousands of new stars into space is approximately 12,960 years apart. Therefore if you now view the stars from closest to furthest, you will find a detectable gap of 12,960 years between the layers of stars. If you can measure the AU between the Sun and the closest star, simply divide that number between 11,268 years and that will give you the velocity, which the stars are traveling away from our Galaxy. Once you determine the 12,960 year gaps between the layers of stars, you will then be able to read them like marks on a tape measure, going as deep into space as visibly possible.

This type of stuff makes me wonder if future space explorers will end up having to give up ALL of their earthly connections in order to explore the far reaches of space. Because of time dilation and relativity, they may end up leaving earth, spending what for them would seem like months or years in space, only to come back and find that decades or even a hundred years have passed with everyone they knew or loved long dead. And I think that this may be one thing that we may never be able to overcome, even if we figure out how to travel faster then light (which WE WILL) we may not ever find a way to overcome time dilations. Space isn't a bunch of stars and galaxies frozen in amber, stuck in their orbits around one another and the galactic center, but rather there moving, every changing and forever getting farther apart and more isolated from one another. Its kind of sad when you really think about it. That one day everything in our universe will be so far spread out that should humans still exist on some distant "New Earth" you'd look up and see nothing but a big, empty, black nothingness void of stars, galaxies or super novas of any kind, rendering space exploration either from space or terrestrial..... impossible.

There's a time delay when radio signals or light travels close to the sun (or whatever large mass) is because of warped space.

What causes warped space? Merely objects being in space causes warped space. The mass of the objects causes the fabric of space to be displaced. Now that area is taken up by the mass. And the fabric of space is now in multiples around the object.

So as light or whatever travels through this multiple of spacetime, it takes longer.

All this is possible because the universe is constantly expanding.

Nice video. Unfortunately a slight error: you mentioned the a contribution to the time-delay comes from the fact that the wide-angled rays travelled further than the shallow-angled rays, but this is false. The reason why the rays "bend" is because the speed of propagation changes and thus causing the wavefront to curve, and as a result the optical path length (and hence delay) is the same regardless which path is taken. This of course neglects dispersion and time-dilation and assumes perfect imaging. As the time-dilation in our own solar system showed, I presume that is the dominant effect for the time-delay.

What if, as the universe expands, the general speed of light increases? Meaning, if we had a window into the future we would observe everything moving faster. This does not affect the Doppler shift, which only cares about the 'stretching out' of light as it moves, since all 'parts' of light will be speeding up at the same time so there will be no differential that would be evidenced in the color shift. However it may 'speed up' other observable cosmic activity, meaning light reaches us faster than expected if it were moving at a 'constant' speed. Therefore the calculated expansion rate of some methods gives a lower result.

Then it becomes understandable that galaxies tend to form a higher density of this space medium ( Halo) , which produces the lensing effect, and has nothing to do with gravitational fields.

So it is more likely an artefact than a supernova.

The interpretation of Isaac Newton's texts has sparked controversy to this day. One of the
most heated debates relates to the action between two bodies distant from each other (the
gravitational attraction), and to what extent Newton involved God in this case. Practically, most
of the papers discuss four types of gravitational attractions in the case of remote bodies: direct
distance action as intrinsic property of bodies in epicurean sense; direct remote action divinely
mediated by God; remote action mediated by a material ether; or remote action mediated by an
immaterial ether. The purpose of this paper is to argue that Newton categorically rejected the types
of direct action as the intrinsic property of bodies, and remote action mediated by a material ether.
Concerning the other two types of action, direct through divine intervention and mediated through
an immaterial environment, Newton has repeatedly stated that he does not know the exact cause
of gravity, but in both cases, he has directly involved God, directly in the first case and as the
primary cause (the environment/ether being the secondary cause) in immaterial mediated action.
But since recognition of direct distance action could have given some credit to those who thought
gravity could be essential to matter, and hence to atheism, Newton never openly acknowledged
the possibility of such an idea. Towards the end of his life, Newton leaned more toward a remote
action mediated by an immaterial ether. In the argumentation of this opinion, I turned to the works
of Andrew Janiak, Eric Schliesser John Henry, Hylarie Kochiras and Steffen Ducheyne.

Four letters from Sir Isaac Newton to Doctor Bentley... (I stroked the text to be easily spotted)
In February of 1693, after receiving three letters from Newton, Bentley wrote an extensive reply that attempted to characterize Newton's theory of gravity, and his understanding of the nature of matter, in a way that could be used to undermine various kinds of atheism. With the three earlier letters as his guide, Bentley makes the following estimation of Newton's understanding of the possibility that gravity could somehow be an essential feature of material bodies:

"And as for gravitation, tis impossible that that should either be coæternal & essential to matter, or ever acquired by it. Not essential and coæternal to matter; for then even our system would have been eternal (if gravity could form it) against our atheist's supposition & what we have proved in our last. For let them assign any given time, that matter convened from a chaos into our system, they must affirm that before the given time matter gravitated eternally without convening, which is absurd. {Sir, I make account, that your courteous suggestion by your last, that a chaos is inconsistent with the hypothesis of innate gravity, is included in this paragraph of mine.} and again, tis unconceivable, that inanimate brute matter should (without a divine impression) operate upon & affect other matter without mutual contact: as it must, if gravitation be essential and inherent in it."

In reply to this letter, Newton refers back to this second proposition, making one of the most famous of all his pronouncements concerning the possibility of action at a distance:

"The last clause of the second position I like very well. It is inconceivable that inanimate brute matter should, without the mediation of something else which is not material, operate upon and affect other matter without mutual contact, as it must be, if gravitation in the sense of Epicurus, be essential and inherent in it. And this is one reason why I desired you would not ascribe innate gravity to me. That gravity should be innate, inherent, and essential to matter, so that one body may act upon another at a distance through a vacuum, without the mediation of anything else, by and through which their action and force may be conveyed from one to another, is to me so great an absurdity that I believe no man who has in philosophical matters a competent faculty of thinking can ever fall into it. Gravity must be caused by an agent acting constantly according to certain laws; but whether this agent be material or immaterial, I have left open to the consideration of my readers"

Note that while supernovae are statistically rare since stars tend to form at the same time so it is quite clear but we would be able to tell if they are different.

As for the "possible crisis in cosmology" as multiple methods and measurements have been made and surveys formed it seems the earlier 74 km/MPc and other similar values have been preferentially focused on one of two directions in the sky (because the Milky Way blocks much of the rest of the sky)
Recent work in other parts of the electromagnetic spectrum have found that the rate at which galaxies are receding as of around 6 billion years ago happens to have started to become significantly anisotropic. We don't know why per say is it an observational bias much stronger than predicted? Or did something happen say the mutual gravity of galaxies drop below some initial intrinsic bias or is Dark energy itself inhomogeneously spread throughout the Universe resulting in the rate of expansion varying by direction since then? Interestingly in some directions the rate of expansion does appear to be decelerating where as on the other extreme it seems to be speeding up even faster than 74 Km/MPc It is strangely weird

It also should be noted that Type Ia supernovae have turned out to be far worse as standard candles than expected due to multiple ways White dwarfs can reach the state and the stars seeming to destabilize below this threshold and at different places with different outcomes etc.

Many of our Theories are conclusions based on prior speculations that we think might be accurate, but we don't actually know are absolutely true.

So one thing I wonder is, could the discrepancy between measurements of the cosmic expansion rate result from a faulty assumption underlying the use of type Ia supernovae standard candles? Namely, that assumption itself depends on a further assumption that virtually all type Ia supernovae result from  a white dwarf accreting matter from a binary partner, and thus go supernova right at the Chandrasekhar limit, producing the same luminosity every time. But if it were to turn out that a significant portion of type Ia supernovae result from collisions between two white dwarfs instead - which could result in a whole range of potential luminosities due to the combined mass being able to significantly exceed the Chandrasekhar limit - then wouldn't that break their utility as a standard candle and everything that depends on that, including measurements of the cosmic expansion rate? Or are there spectral features expected to be seen in white dwarf collisional Ia supernovae that wouldn't be present in accretional ones?

I actually study this galaxy cluster! We call it macks-jay eleven fourty-nine for short. This cluster is rich with scientific potential! I study the black holes at the center of galaxies, active galactic nuclei or AGN, and look for changes in brightness over time, and MACSJ1149 has many AGN ripe for study! Fun fact: this was also the cluster where the farthest star ever discovered was found, precisely because of gravitational lensing! This star just so happened to move exactly into the path of the cluster lens path, so its light was magnified extraordinarily! It's called MACSJ1149 Lensed Star 1 if you want to learn more about it!

Space itself is an interesting problem. We can't see it as necessarily expanding as there is only 1 observer. Everyone contained within the universe will see precisely the same effect. All observations of expansion is a local statement, regardless of your location and all will provide an identical result. Where relativity lacks is when space is expanding from a second frame of reference. No observer can measure expansion from outside of the universe. So is it accurate to say its expanding or space is created within space? "

Thats why i love Astronomy, the sheer size and magnificence of it all. I mean Just one example is our Sun(which makes up 99.86% of our solar systems mass) is approximately 93  million miles away (which is 1 Astronomical Unit, from center of earth to center of sun) and light takes roughly 8 minutes to reach us and the Sun converts 600 million tons of hydrogen into 596 million tons of helium every second! in a constant battle of equilibrium with gravity that it will eventually lose.  Now lets take Beetlegeus for example, as shown is 548 Light years from Earth (Light year is the distance light travels in 1 Earth year= about 6 trillion miles) which is incredible when you realize that outer space is just 62 miles away, Although there is no official solid boundary for where space begins, the Kármán line sits at 62 miles above sea-level and is conventionally used as the start of outer space in space treaties or for aerospace records keeping. But its not just that but the fact A neutron star( Neutron stars are formed when a massive star runs out of fuel and collapses and can spin 600 times/sec. The very central region of the star – the core – collapses, crushing together every proton and electron into a neutron) is about 20 km in diameter and has the mass of about 1.4 times that of our Sun. This means that a neutron star is so dense that on Earth, one teaspoonful would weigh a billion tons!  Even to the fact that Quasars are the brightest thing in our universe and that stars you see at night could have "gone out" millions of years ago to the fact that supernovas are incredibly powerful, as a matter of fact the most powerful explosion puts the “super” in supernova. A blast about 4.5 million light-years away has released about 10 times more energy than the sun will emit in its entire lifetime, making it the most powerful supernova ever spotted, named "SN2016aps". Not only is SN2016aps the most powerful supernova ever spotted, it is the longest one we have found. We found this more than three years ago, and we’re still observing it – usually we only can track a supernova for maybe a few months, and thats not even scratching the surface.

This was a great video on a great topic. I would just like to remark a small thing. The main reason why we see the SN appear at different times is not the Shapiro delay, that is, not because time flows at a different pace in a stronger gravitational field (that effect does exist, but is not relevant in this context). The delays are simply due to the different length of the curved paths that the light follows from the different images of the SN. As shown very clearly in the graphics in the video, some paths are longer than others, so light takes longer to reach us. In a sense, it's surprising that the time differences are so small, as it took around 10 billion years for the light to reach us, and the individual flight times only differ by 20 years or so.

But there is a redshift controversy in which the redshift could mean something else than expressing the expansion of the Universe. A professional astronomer named Halton Arp has discovered a pattern between QASARs and its nearby galaxy in which Redshift could possibly mean the slowing down of the speed of a QASAR that was ejected from the center of its nearby galaxy (so the redshift, instead of being the speed of recession of an object moving away from us (on Earth), would possibly be related instead, to the speed of recession of an object moving away FROM WHERE IT WAS EJECTED). If he's right about his hypothesis, then his finding would invalidate the big bang theory. It would be interesting to see this channel Veritasium make a video on Halton Arp findings.
